pullRequest.body:
In this PR, we implements datatypes which is used in `cc` tactic.
Also, `Init.CCLemmas` is removed in #10696, but this module is required for `cc` tactic, so we recover this module as `Tactic.CC.Lemmas`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: My English in the documents is possibly poor, please correct.

I think this is ready to get merged with a few last tweaks. Thanks!

bors d+

:v: Komyyy can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8817589319/job/24204332348)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8817589319/job/24204331202)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8817589319/job/24204331568)
Overall this looks good, thanks for the hard work in porting! I think it's important to get this documented well while you still understand how the CC tactic works. Otherwise I have minor changes.

I think I understand now what each of the datastructures is intended to do, and I have written some documentation strings. Could you please check that my suggestions are correct? If you agree with a suggested docstring, please apply it. Otherwise, could you try to write a correct docstring?

```suggestion
 ["unusedArguments", "Decidable.not_or_iff_and_not"],
```
Should these two functions also check for `OfScientific` (i.e. decimal number constants)?

Currently, `cc` lacks an ability to handle decimal number constants.
I don't think these functions should check for `OfScientific`.

Maybe the word "constant" or "literal" will make it clearer what precisely is intended here.
```suggestion
/-- Return true if `e` represents a constant value (numeral, character, or string). -/
```

```suggestion
/-- Return true if `e` represents a value (nat/int numeral, character, or string).

In addition to the conditions in `Mathlib.Tactic.CC.isValue`, this also checks that
kernel computation can compare the values for equality.
-/
```

Let's annotate the terms being constructed, with their expected form.
```suggestion
  -- `motive :  x, a = x  Prop := fun x h => R a x`
  let motive 
```

```suggestion
  -- `minor : R a a := by rfl`
  let minor  do
```
Is there a reason you chose red-black maps instead of `HashMap` like for `ExtCongrTheoremCache`?

I don't know.
I just rewrote the cc tactic code written in C++ into Lean.
Please ask @leodemoura.

I suppose we'll leave it this way and when `cc` is used more commonly we can do some profiling.
```suggestion
/-- Red-black maps whose keys are `Expr`s.

TODO: the choice between `RBMap` and `HashMap` is not obvious:
the current version follows the Lean 3 C++ implementation.
Once the `cc` tactic is used a lot in Mathlib, we should profile and see
if `HashMap` could be more optimal.
-/
abbrev RBExprMap ( : Type u) := Std.RBMap Expr  compare

/-- Red-black sets of `Expr`s.

TODO: the choice between `RBSet` and `HashSet` is not obvious:
the current version follows the Lean 3 C++ implementation.
Once the `cc` tactic is used a lot in Mathlib, we should profile and see
if `HashSet` could be more optimal.
-/
abbrev RBExprSet := Std.RBSet Expr compare
```

The name `ExtCongrTheorem` suggests this involves extensionality. What do you think about:
```suggestion
structure HeqCongrTheorem extends CongrTheorem where
```

```suggestion
/-- Automatically generated congruence lemma based on heterogeneous equality.

This returns an annotated version of the result from `Lean.Meta.mkHCongrWithArity`.
-/
```
Should this produce a more detailed message, along the lines of "mkExtHCongrWithArity: type should be `Eq` or `HEq`: {type}"?

According to the implemention of `mkHCongrWithArity`,`type.isHEq` is always `true`.
I removed this `guard`.
Note for reviewers: According to the diff, this is a new line.

Note for reviewers: the following lines were removed here:

```lean
-theorem ne_of_eq_of_ne { : Sort u} {a b c : } (h : a = b) (h : b  c) : a  c :=
-  h.symm  h
-
-alias Eq.trans_ne := ne_of_eq_of_ne
-#align eq.trans_ne Eq.trans_ne
-
-theorem ne_of_ne_of_eq { : Sort u} {a b c : } (h : a  b) (h : b = c) : a  c :=
-  h  h
-
-alias Ne.trans_eq := ne_of_ne_of_eq
-#align ne.trans_eq Ne.trans_eq
```

These can now be found in `Mathlib.Logic.Basic`.

Could you explain what happens if `ignoreInstances` is false?

Does setting this to `true` mean that CC might fail on the following example?
```lean
example {G : Type*} [AddCommMonoid G] (a b : G) :
    @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddCommSemigroup.toAddSemigroup)) a b =
      @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddMonoid.toAddSemigroup)) b a := by
  cc
```
Since the add comes from two different instances.

Actually, your example doesn't fail due to AC module, but it fails when `ac` is false.
It's almost what you think it is.

Sorry, I don't quite understand your reply. Let me try asking again: does the `cc` tactic solve the example by default? If that does not work by default, then I predict many complaints about `cc` not working.

Apart from that, I am not sure what the `ignoreInstances` option actually does: do you know an example where the different effects of this option are demonstrated?

> does the `cc` tactic solve the example by default?
Yes.
```lean
example {G : Type*} [AddCommMonoid G] (a b : G) :
    @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddCommSemigroup.toAddSemigroup)) a b =
      @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddMonoid.toAddSemigroup)) b a := by
  cc
```

And, even if `ignoreInstances` is `false`, the example doesn't fail due to AC module.
```lean
example {G : Type*} [AddCommMonoid G] (a b : G) :
    @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddCommSemigroup.toAddSemigroup)) a b =
      @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddMonoid.toAddSemigroup)) b a := by
  cc (config := { ignoreInstances := false })
```

But, it fails when `ac` is false.
```lean
example {G : Type*} [AddCommMonoid G] (a b : G) :
    @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddCommSemigroup.toAddSemigroup)) a b =
      @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddMonoid.toAddSemigroup)) b a := by
  success_if_fail_with_msg "cc tactic failed"
    cc (config := { ignoreInstances := false, ac := false })
  cc
```

>> I am not sure what the ignoreInstances option actually does: do you know an example where the different effects of this option are demonstrated?
```lean
example {G : Type*} [AddCommMonoid G] (a b : G) :
    @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddCommSemigroup.toAddSemigroup)) a b =
      @HAdd.hAdd _ _ _ (@instHAdd _ (@AddSemigroup.toAdd _ AddMonoid.toAddSemigroup)) a b := by
  success_if_fail_with_msg "cc tactic failed"
    cc (config := { ignoreInstances := false, ac := false })
  cc (config := { ac := false })
```

I see, thanks!

```suggestion
  /-- If `true`, congruence closure will treat implicit instance arguments as constants.
  
  This means that setting `ignoreInstances := false` will fail to unify two definitionally equal instances
  of the same class. (Note however that `ac := true` also performs work to unify instances
  and therefore some goals are solved anyway.)
  -/
```

```suggestion
  /-- If `true`, congruence closure modulo Associativity and Commutativity. -/
```

This coercion seems likely to give a subtle bug when called on an `Expr` that is already an application of a binary operator. I'd rather have an explicit function, or check for associativity/commutativity in the coercion.

If you keep this coercion, please put `attribute [coe] ACApps.ofExpr`. We use the attribute throughout Mathlib for coercion operators, to display and treat them equally in tactics. I suppose we won't be proving much about `ACApps` here, but it's good practice.

```suggestion
/-- Ordering on `ACApps` sorts `.ofExpr` before `.apps`, and sorts `.apps` by function symbol, then by shortlex order. -/
```

```suggestion
Example: The result is `true` for `e := a*a*a*b*d` and `e := a*a*a*a*b*b*c*d*d`.
The result is also `true` for `e := a` and `e := a*a*a*b*c`.
 -/
```

Indenting inside these docstrings will result in quoted text in the Markdown renderer. Could you also fix this below?

```suggestion
Example: given `e := a*a*a*a*b*b*c*d*d*d` and `e := a*a*a*b*b*d`,
the result is `#[a, c, d, d]`

Precondition: `e.isSubset e` -/
```

To be a bit more explicit about the function:
```suggestion
/-- Appends elements of the set difference `e \ e` to `r`.
```

If I understand the semantics of `isSubset` correctly:
```suggestion
  | .ofExpr _ => if e == e then r else r.push e
```

Could you explain why we need to check that the operator is indeed `op`?
```suggestion
/-- Appends arguments of `e` to `r`, only when `e` is an application of the operator `op`. -/
```

I don't know.
I just rewrote the cc tactic code written in C++ into Lean.
Please ask @leodemoura.

```suggestion
  /-- An `ACApps` of applications of a binary operator. `args` are assumed to be sorted.

See also `ACApps.mkApps` if `args` are not yet sorted.
-/
```

```suggestion
  let newArgs := ACApps.append op e #[]
  let newArgs := ACApps.append op e newArgs
  -- TODO: this does a full sort but `newArgs` consists of two sorted subarrays,
  -- so if we want to optimize this, some form of merge sort might be faster.
  ACApps.mkApps op newArgs
```
This is also a `RBMap`, should this also be a `HashMap`?

I don't know.
I just rewrote the cc tactic code written in C++ into Lean.
Please ask @leodemoura.

``
```suggestion
/-- Red-black maps whose keys are `ACApps`es.

TODO: the choice between `RBMap` and `HashMap` is not obvious:
the current version follows the Lean 3 C++ implementation.
Once the `cc` tactic is used a lot in Mathlib, we should profile and see
if `HashMap` could be more optimal.
-/
abbrev RBACAppsMap ( : Type u) := Std.RBMap ACApps  compare

/-- Red-black sets of `ACApps`es.

TODO: the choice between `RBSet` and `HashSet` is not obvious:
the current version follows the Lean 3 C++ implementation.
Once the `cc` tactic is used a lot in Mathlib, we should profile and see
if `HashSet` could be more optimal.
-/
abbrev RBACAppsSet := Std.RBSet ACApps compare
```

```suggestion
instance : Coe Expr DelayedExpr := DelayedExpr.ofExpr
attribute [coe] DelayedExpr.ofExpr
```

```suggestion
instance : Coe Expr EntryExpr := EntryExpr.ofExpr
attribute [coe] EntryExpr.ofExpr
```

If it's unused, let's indeed remove it.
```suggestion
```
Could you explain what `R` stands for? I assume `LHS` and `RHS` mean `Left-Hand-Side` and `Right-Hand-Side`.
`CCState.acR`

```suggestion
  /-- Expressions that occur on the left hand side of an equality in `CCState.acR`. -/
  RLHSOccs : RBACAppsSet := 
  /-- Expressions that occur on the right hand side of an equality in `CCState.acR`. -/
  RRHSOccs : RBACAppsSet := 
```

```suggestion
/-- Returns the occurrences of this entry in either the LHS or RHS. -/
def ACEntry.ROccs (ent : ACEntry) : (inLHS : Bool)  RBACAppsSet
```

Actually, I don't know if `RLHSOccs` stands for the occurrences of this entry in the LHS.
Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.
Please ask @leodemoura.
If I understand the way this is used in `composeAC`, I think my docstring is correct.
Could you explain (in a comment) how `ParentOcc` and `Parents` are used?

I don't know.
I just rewrote the cc tactic code written in C++ into Lean.
Please ask @leodemoura.

If I understand usages of `propagateUp` correctly:
```suggestion
/-- Used to record when an expression processed by `cc` occurs in another expression. -/
structure ParentOcc where
```
Do `fo` and `ho` mean First-Order and Higher-Order here?
Yes.

```suggestion
  /-- `fn` is First-Order: we do not consider all partial applications. -/
  | fo (fn : Expr) (args : Array Expr) : CongruencesKey
  /-- `fn` is Higher-Order. -/
  | ho (fn : Expr) (arg : Expr) : CongruencesKey
```

```suggestion
/-- Update the `CCState` by constructing and inserting a new `Entry`. -/
def CCState.mkEntryCore (ccs : CCState) (e : Expr) (interpreted : Bool) (constructor : Bool)
```

Do I understand the purpose of this function correctly?
```suggestion
/-- Is the expression in an equivalence class with only one element (namely, itself)? -/
def inSingletonEqc (ccs : CCState) (e : Expr) : Bool :=
```

```suggestion
"Modification Time". The field `mt` is used to implement the mod-time optimization introduced by the
```

```suggestion
/-- Append to `roots` all the roots of equivalence classes in `ccs`.

If `nonsingletonOnly` is true, we skip all the singleton equivalence classes.
-/
def getRoots (ccs : CCState) (roots : Array Expr) (nonsingletonOnly : Bool) : Array Expr :=
```
What is the purpose of this function? Is it more of a debugging check for integrity of the CCState?
Yes.

```suggestion
/-- Check for integrity of the `CCState`. -/
def checkEqc (ccs : CCState) (e : Expr) : Bool :=
```
What is the purpose of this function? Is it more of a debugging check for integrity of the CCState?
Yes.

```suggestion
/-- Check for integrity of the `CCState`. -/
def checkInvariant (ccs : CCState) : Bool :=
```
What does `var` mean in this context? I assume it's not a `Expr.bvar`/`Expr.fvar`?
`Entry.acVar`

```suggestion
/-- Search for the AC-variable (`Entry.acVar`) with the least occurrences in the state. -/
def getVarWithLeastOccs (ccs : CCState) (e : ACApps) (inLHS : Bool) : Option Expr :=
```

```suggestion
/-- Used to map an expression `e` to another expression that contains `e`.

When `e` is normalized, its parents should also change.
-/
abbrev Parents := RBExprMap ParentOccSet
```

```suggestion
/-- Maps each expression (via `mkCongruenceKey`) to expressions it might be congruent to. -/ 
abbrev Congruences := Std.HashMap CongruencesKey (List Expr)
```

```suggestion
/-- The symmetric variant of `Congruences`.

The `Name` identifies which relation the congruence is considered for.
Note that this only works for two-argument relations: `ModEq n` and `ModEq m` are considered the same.
-/
abbrev SymmCongruences := Std.HashMap SymmCongruencesKey (List (Expr  Name))
```

```suggestion
  /-- Maps known expressions to their equivalence class data. -/
  entries : Entries := 
```

```suggestion
  /-- Maps an expression `e` to the expressions `e` occurs in. -/
  parents : Parents := 
```

```suggestion
  /-- Maps each expression to a set of expressions it might be congruent to. -/
  congruences : Congruences := 
  /-- Maps each expression to a set of expressions it might be congruent to,
  via the symmetrical relation. -/
  symmCongruences : SymmCongruences := 
```

```suggestion
  /-- Records which instances of the same class are defeq. -/
  instImplicitReprs : InstImplicitReprs := 
```

```suggestion
  /-- Extra `Entry` information used by the AC part of the tactic. -/
  acEntries : RBExprMap ACEntry := 
```

```suggestion
  /-- Records equality between `ACApps`. -/
  acR : RBACAppsMap (ACApps  DelayedExpr) := 
```

```suggestion
/-- `CCStructure` extends `CCState` (which records a set of facts derived by congruence closure)
by recording which steps still need to be taken to solve the goal.
-/
structure CCStructure extends CCState where
```

```suggestion
  /-- Equalities that have been discovered but not processed. -/
  todo : Array TodoEntry := #[]
  /-- AC-equalities that have been discovered but not processed. -/
  acTodo : Array ACTodoEntry := #[]
```

nodes.body: My English in the documents is possibly poor, please correct.
Overall this looks good, thanks for the hard work in porting! I think it's important to get this documented well while you still understand how the CC tactic works. Otherwise I have minor changes.

I think I understand now what each of the datastructures is intended to do, and I have written some documentation strings. Could you please check that my suggestions are correct? If you agree with a suggested docstring, please apply it. Otherwise, could you try to write a correct docstring?

I think this is ready to get merged with a few last tweaks. Thanks!
